There you go. The fact that he can get through one video without blatantly showing his ass doesn't tell you much. Haz has literally said that "class struggle is irrelevant," just like his hero Dugin thinks. Putting aside all the conservative shit about "trans nazis" he's not even right about the foundational class issues. He's a very confused guy who makes it up as he goes, so at best perhaps he's grown out of some of his more crack pipe opinions but I have never heard him say so.

replies.author: @Justin72130
replies.text: Haz spent about 7:40 to 12:50 denying the existence of industrial capital. He claims that these industrial capitalists have been subsumed by finance capital therefore according to haz, not only do they not exist, but that the remnants of these industrial capitalists dont pose a threat to any working class movement that should arise in this country. Do you know who else vehemently denounced finance capital while allying himself with industrialists? Adolf Hitler. Hazs ideas are too close to fascism for comfort, anyone who has studied history should be able to see this. Thats why im so disappointed in Carlos for not pushing back AT ALL, you can tell he knows better, yet I think mwm views an alliance with people like haz who espouse more economic nationalism than socialism as beneficial to building a socialist movement in the USA, I guess we will see, but its a dangerous game to play.

@Justin72130ok Fashbuster ‚Äî except he absolutely didn‚Äôt deny this, why are you lying. He said, and he‚Äôs correct, that industrial
capital has been swallowed up by finance capital and he‚Äôs correct. These large industrial companies main source of value is not derived from fruits of their production but from their debt and financing. That‚Äôs all he‚Äôs saying. Try and listen and not react.

author: @ludviglidstrom6924
text: Yeah, but the VOTING BASE of Fascism was the petit-bourgeoisie and the farmers, as opposed to the proletariat for example. The capitalist class is too small to yield enough votes, although they of course funded the Fascists. But I‚Äôm not saying that the policies of the Fascists actually benefited their voting base.

replies.author: @antoinebenobre2552
replies.text: Indeed. When Dimitrov says fascism is the terrorist and open dictatorship of the most chauvinistic and reactionary elements of finance capital, he is right at every level, but he talks about FASCISM as a political SYSTEM. But when reading Big Business with Hitler by Jacques Pauwels, or any other book on this subject, you easily understand that all FASCISTS are not finance capitalists. Were the SA all traders and bankers ? Was it all bankers that voted at 30% for Hitler ? That's a lot of bankers ! The sociological component of the SA was mostly petit bourgeoisie, bureaucracy, public workers such as teachers, some peasants, lumpenproletariat... And one third of proletariat ! There is something to study into this small attraction the fascist rethoric has over some part of the proletariat, and this study has been made. And even the highest ranking nazis were, for some, bankers, but most of them were not. They were also petit bourgeois, former cadres of the republic that kept their work, intellectuals etc. But the finance capitalists themselves ? The one that really are the shareholders of companies and the main investors of imperialism ? What are they ? Some of them are indeed strictly fascists, we know of the infamous Henry Ford. But most of them were not, they were what Jacques calls "philofascists", people that love the fascists, that support the fascists, that make the fascists rise. But, and that's the best proof of the infrastructural soil of fascism, they do not care. They do not care if it is against Jews or Poles or anyone that gets blasted or not blasted. What they care about is what fascists delivered : anti union policies, anti communist policies, liberalization, privatization, fierce imperialism etc etc... That is why this system is their open dictatorship. Because if the fascists decide of the secondary elements (racism, culture etc), it is the finance capitalists that support their favourite tendancy among fascists, and make it happen, the one that will be fully bent to their will : the most reactionary.

replies.text: @edsymoI think they honestly do the exact same thing just through different paradigms. Infrared has a large poc and working class following too. I know it‚Äôs easy to miss when you just see ‚Äúangry man yell‚Äù. Which is something Haz is trying to put behind him by the way.

replies.author: @edsymo
replies.text: @EggEnjoyer One of his videos is Mao and Stalin were 'libertarians', that is something I just can't take infrared too seriously, unlike Midwestern Marx and others

replies.author: @EggEnjoyer
replies.text:
@edsymo Are you aware that libertarianism comes first socialist? They were called libertarian socialists. They were the first to adopt the term. They were socialist who didn‚Äôt believe in large governmental oversight.
Now I will admit that the title of his video is inflammatory and intentionally so. But if you just read the description of the video, he explains his position and says that Mao and Stalin are often accused of even authoritarian. But in reality they did everything they could to limit government oversight and leave governance to the locals and not on the federal level. It‚Äôs a very good point. Us Marxist are often accused of being authoritarians but in reality, the end of out philosophy is a society with no government.

You can call infrared out for being inflammatory. But when it comes to the substance, he‚Äôs on point and is serious. Like the video you just mentioned, behind the title, the content is not wrong or pig headed as the title would make you think. In fact it even open a bridge to libertarians and returns the title of libertarian back to us Marxist. Who believes in smaller than governments than us? We believe in no government lol.
Haz is a goofy guy and he does some outlandish things, so I get if that‚Äôs a turn off. But his substance is always on point

replies.author: @edsymo
replies.text:
@EggEnjoyer Probably but, most libertarian socialists reject material or historical conditions. Commonly thinking that the human civilisation develops based on ideals, and generally lack any revolutionary theory that goes beyond spontaneous action and other idealistic notions, libertarian socialists can be largely viewed as modern utopian socialists.
A large amount of libertarian socialists are anarchists, who Stalin and Mao both heavily criticised and dismissed. Libertarian socialist movements have yet to gain the same historical relevance or state power as past-or-present scientific socialists have.

replies.author: @EggEnjoyer
replies.text:
@edsymo Like I said the title is purposely inflammatory. And you‚Äôre allowed to not like that. 
But Haz‚Äôs main point was that Stalin and Mao weren‚Äôt authoritarian and that in many way they prevented big government overreach

replies.author: @xCobraCommanderxFreePalestine
replies.text:
I believe you are both correct. Both as in You and Carlos. Not the other person who commented here. 

I mean I feel the same way about Liberals. Yet it is our duty to reach them even the Bernie Bros. I do not have the luxury to give up or put blinders on. I want this whole planet RED, and if we don‚Äôt reach them someone else will. So to me I don‚Äôt draw a ‚Äúred line‚Äù when it comes to Conservatives, Moderates, and even self proclaimed Socialists. I don‚Äôt see this as demonizing the working class unless it‚Äôs from the perspective of the Ultra mentality. IE ‚ÄúHaz is X and I don‚Äôt want to help X people.‚Äù When the reality is NOBODY agrees but EVERYONE knows something is wrong. This is where we are right now. The masses have questions, have grievances, and they need answers. 

As far as Haz himself idk. I don‚Äôt have twitter or Facebook or any social media. I hope he‚Äôs grown and become more professional over the last few years vs how he first came on the scene calling everyone a Regard and conflating Biden LGBTQ+ Trojan Horse Human Rights with actually oppressed LGBTQ+ folks.

replies.author: @dustjamesamerica
replies.text: ‚Äã@xCobraCommanderx We as individuals have little significance. Prompting Haz isn't supporting him or his cult of insecure trolls ect., it's helping achieve the establishment's goal to paint him and others like him as the legitimate representation of Communism, while Haz is a divisive, rightfully hated troll, hated not by "leftoids", but rightfully  by the working class and oppressed themselves.

author: @ximauri
text:
Haz is right-wing. Debate bros are not Marxist, they use slimy tactics to trick their opponents into gotcha moments and they make content for entertainment and not to advance class struggle. If you've ever seen haz actually try to make a point, it's frighteningly close to something coming out of a right-wingers mouth. He argued that you shouldn't give indigenous Americans their land back because they're now a small portion of the population (yikes) in the Jason Unruhe debate. Just look at his chat, his fanbase is completely filled with toxic trolls. This isn't Marxism guys, it's clear, this is reactionary. 

And to Carlos and mwm, y'all have some great educational content and have earned many people's respect, but platforming someone like this only serves to discredit your name.

replies.author: @hottakeco-op2510
replies.text: The issue with the landback mvmt, in addition to its impracticality, is the NDN collective. Infrared isn't opposed to indigenous sovereignty in principle, but concretely even you must admit the scope of this would be limited by the reality that, yes, this is a tiny tiny fraction of the population today. Practically speaking, any actually existing landback would take forms similiar to the autonomous regions within the PRC. And if you deny this not only are you idealist, but implicitly propose something fundamentally reactionary, proposing the clock to be wound back to a lower stage of integration and development. There is a reason Marx and Engels described America as a world historic progressive development, and it wasn't because they were unaware of the atrocities committed to the indigenous. Your issue isn't with infrared, but with Marxism itself I'm afraid.

replies.author: @pop√¢ndƒÉunedelius-z1i
replies.text:
your historical interpretation reeks of "Western Marxism" with rotten Trotsky-type characteristics. 

Russia, China and Iran of the present 21st century have no political-economic-administrative resemblance to the empires of the pre-World War I period. All the empires before the First World War were in decline or decadence, starting with the most developed British empire (as conquered territories or colonies under administration), continuing with the French, Italian, Ottoman, Tsarist or Austro-Hungarian, even the newly emerged empires like Germany or the United States had major economic or financial-capitalist-monopolistic problems.  In the period between 1890-1900, the United States experienced a major economic crisis temporarily stopped by the "protectionist tariffs" and other reforms of McKinley, a crisis temporarily stopped because those so-called reforms culminated in the great depression of 1929. Lenin was only watching and studying carefully the decline of the British and Tsarist empires, and perhaps Germany, but the other emerging empires were in major crisis as well. 

Russia, Iran and China of the present times do not have the problems that the financial empires of Germany and the United States had in the period 1980-1914. Another important thing, the British, French, Italian empires did not impose economic and trade sanctions against the new emerging empires of Germany or the United States for carrying out massacres in Zimbabwe, the Philippines or Hawaii, as is currently the case with the sanctions imposed on China, Iran and Russia for so-called violations of human rights and the international order of law.  There were no proxy wars of empires then, with armies of sophisticated terrorists and na»õzis making color revolutions or Maidans. Indeed, Russia, Iran and China are much more socialist than the imperialist Western nations ever will be, nor will socialism be implemented in Western Europe or North America in 500 years. Because Trotskyist literature alongside the liberal Hollywood industry, through films, books, cartoons and video games, prepare new generations of their children propagandistically and culturally for the next era of the feudal system.

replies.author: @Justin72130
replies.text: @mp1652 inferred spent 7:40 to 12:50 in this video claiming that industrial capital has been abolished by finance capital, and therefore not even the remnants of industrial capital stand in opposition to a proletarian revolution. This is not only wrong (industrial capital still exists even if it exists as secondary to finance capital) but it is also ahistorical. The petite bourgeoise ie: small industrial capitalists, merchants etc. have historically stood in opposition to proletarian revolutions across the globe, there is very little to suggest the modern American petite bourgeoise would act any differently. It seems fair to draw the conclusion from this conversation that haz would be willing to ally himself with industrial capital in order to further the goal of destroying international finance capital. Do you know who else allied himself with industrialists while vehemently opposing finance capital? Adolf Hitler. the alliance with national industrial capitalists is a core distinction between fascists like infrared and real socialists.

replies.author: @mp1652
replies.text:
‚Äã@Justin72130 according to transcript, he says "subsumed" not "abolished." That is, industrial capital has been overtaken by finance capital - he's saying it doesn't exist as an independent political or economic force from finance. His point was, per Lenin, Industrial capital represents the form bourgeois power takes, and our analysis of capital should operate from that standpoint, as opposed to pretending the global economy works the same way it did in 1870. That's a pretty standard Leninist approach.

Why would he ally with something he says doesn't exist anymore? Where does he even say "industrial capital = good guys?"

As for Hitler, Hitler's rise to power was funded by finance capital. That support was essential; having the backing of industrial capitalists was of secondary importance to his power. So, the case of Hitler actually supports what Haz says here: to understand the dynamics of late stage imperialism, study finance capitalism.

author: @WSRFilms
text:
2:08:17 Haz has to explain how he defines socialism. He says he wants to avoid "walking on a minefield" which is odd. He claims he wants to avoid answering the question directly. He then proceeds to answer directly. 
"I mean a mode of production that is based on some kind of, some kind of socially established content and some kind of socially established necessaity. I don't know. The transition from exchange value to use value but not use value in the immediate sense but use value in the sense of like, necessary to attend to the necessities of society, of the commons, right?"
Does this sound like socialism to you?
I am partially convinced Haz is popular because nobody actually reads. He knows the words and sounds convincing, seemingly off the top of the dome, but this level of ignorance, or worse purposeful obfuscation, paints a different picture of his intellect or intentions.

replies.author: @thermidorienne
replies.text: What soundbite sized definition of socialism would you offer?

replies.author: @EggEnjoyer
replies.text:
I wonder if you‚Äôll apply your criticism to Marx and Engels as well. Because they too also refused to give socialism a strict definition.

Were Marx and Engels ignorant or purposefully obfuscating as well?
